THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 16, 1930

UNIVERSITY MAKES Hopkins Library Has Followed
SENIORS, JUNIORS
BARN RENOVATIONS
Unusual Lines of Development TO COMPETE FOR
FOR BARNSTORMERS Proximity Of Peabody Has Allowed Emphasis To DEBATING STAFF
Interior of Former Activities
Building to Be Converted
Into Studio
FOUR CANDIDATES
ELECTED TO CLUB
Ness, Harris Make Acting
Staff; Passagno, Green,
Appointed to Production Staff
On Sunday afternoon, at 4 P. M.,
the active members of the Barnstormers Club held a meeting at
Which plans were made for the remainder of the year, new members
Were elected and future policies of
the club were decided upon.
The club considered the improvements to the Barn first. Lester Haas,
the chairman of the committee in
charge of these improvements,
stated that action for rejuvenation
would be taken immediately by the
University authorities as soon as
the club reported what arrangements and color scheme they desired their studio to be furnished
in. The floors are to be scraped
and varnished and made available
for dancing, should the club -wish
to hold their functions there.
Expensee Prohibits Discussion

The expense to the University,
however, prohibited any further decisions to be made final. It is possible to repaint walls a different hue
or to scrape off the paint entirely
and leave only the bare bricks.
The club authorized the chairman
of the improvements committee to
get estimates on the two possibilities for improvements, namely:
Painting or scraping the walls.
Officies To Be Renovated

The offices of the Business Manager and Production Manager are to
be reconstructed and renovated.
There is to be a special room
devoted to the Club members,
rugs on the floor, ashtrays, and all
modern conveniences where the
elite may rest their weary bones between scenes of the play, during
practice seasons or between classes.
It will be a friendly place to convene where the club members may
express philosophical thoughts or
Propose ideals of the future Barnstormers.
Due to indecision on the Club's
Part, there will be a meeting held
cm Wednesday night after the chairman has conferred with the University authorities on the building.
The sole purpose of this meeting is
to discuss the studio possibilities
and other incidentals.

Be Placed On Books Peculiar To Research
When Daniel Coit Gilman,
founder and first president of the
Johns Hopkins University, first
gave serious thought to the proposed
university, he realized that many
books would be necessary to the success of the plan. He therefore
bought up many books concerning
other colleges, both here and abroad.
These books formed the beginning
of the Johns Hopkins library system, that now has accumulated over
4)0,000 bound volumes.
The collection of books in 1874,
when the University was in the embryonic stage. One of the first purchases was that of a one volume
edition of Webster's dictionary, and
onother one of the original volumes
was a Latin grammar, written by
Basil Gildersleeve, who later became
the first Professor of Greek in the
University.
Available Funds Limited

Due to the fact that the funds
available for the purpose of buying
books was very limited, the motivating spirits of the University in
its early days decided to get only
those books that were not available
at other libraries in the city. In
1876, the Peabody .Institute, situated within a few blocks of the lawn
that formed the Hopkins "campus"
had one of the best libraries suited
to scholarly research in this part of
the country, and it was felt to be a
great loss of time and money to try
to duplicate their collection.

As the situation stood at the time
when the Hopkins University moved
into the two converted houses that
were to be its home for some time,
books were bought mainly on request of the faculty and graduate
students. Under this plan, the library came to include volumes that
were especially valuable in research,
and was especially rich in bound
volumes of periodicals. These were
housed in Hopkins Hall in a room
that held two hundred people.
McCoy Gives $600,000

Many gifts increased the number
of volumes until in 1890, the library
outgrew its quarters. J. W. McCoy
bequeathed a fund of $600,000 to
the University which was available
for building purposes, and with this
money, McCoy Hall was built. It
was in the fourth floor of this building that the library found its new
home. Here the departmental library systemn was developed into its
present form. The main idea of this
plan was to put the books as near
to the department headquarters that
they concerned as was possible.
Chemical volumes were placed in
that laboratory, and books pertaining to other subjects were put at the
fingertips of the professors in question.
Further developments in the early
history of the lit4rary, notes as to
famous books and collections that
are now in it, and other items of interest will appear in further issues.

ON J.H.U. RUSHING

EACH FRATERNITY
ALLOTTED ONE DAY
Frats To Draw Lots For
Addressing Freshmen On
Pledge Day
After weeks of discussion and
argument, the Interfraternity Council yesterday reached a final agreement on the 1930-31 rushing season.
All members were present when the
Board convened in the M. E. Hall
at 12:30.
It was decided that the rushing
season would take place between
8:30 A. M. on Wednesday, February 4, and Monday, February 16.
Each fraternity has been allotted a
day upon which it will conduct open
house.
Must Draw Lots

Should more than one fraternity
be represented at the residence of a
rushee, at the termination of the
rushing season, lots will be drawn
for the privilege of first addressing
him.
The fraternities have pledged
themselves to abide by any agreement the Board has reached. It is
the hope of Chairman Yellott that
members of the Board will co-operate in conducting an orderly and
successful rushing season.

EDITORIAL DEPARTMENT

By HUGO D. WEISGALL

I
S ITS title indicates, this
book is an attempt on the
part of Dr. Boas to show the
workings of the modern mind, to
contrast it with the Greek or classical mind, and to show in what these
differences consist.
In the author's preface, which in
a very brilliant manner, sums up the
entire scope of the essay, we find
the following paragraph:

A

In broadest terms, our modern
thought differs in three respects from
the thinking of the past. First—a
shift from final absolute • "truth" to
changing and growing "probability";
Second—the substitution of the notion
that change is growth for the notion
that it is mechanical impact; Third—
the substitution of what may be called
"will" for the "reason" as the source
of human acts.

The rest of the book consists of
an elaboration of the three fundamental differences in modern thinking,
and a Postlude in which the

In consequence of the statistical
thinking, our observations and physical laws are generalizations, subject to correction. Accidents are no
longer unnatural but merely unusual. What used to be called eccentricity in an artist we now very
tolerantly call originality. What was
once considered to be the depths of
human depravity we now call art.
In the second section, Dr. Boas
speaks of the two kinds of change in
the world, mechanical impact and
growth, and how they are related to
the two kinds of thought. How,
there is no reason to believe that
growth, which was first applied to
sciences dealing with life, will be
applied to the physical sciences as
well, and how the trend of modern
science is statistical. He then speaks
of the mechanical way of thinking
which makes all change mechanical
impact, and has in this chapter one
of the most brilliant short histories
of the evolution of the God Idea I
have seen for years. I cannot refrain from quoting this passage.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 16, 1930

UNIVERSITY MAKES Hopkins Library Has Followed
SENIORS, JUNIORS
BARN RENOVATIONS
Unusual Lines of Development TO COMPETE FOR
FOR BARNSTORMERS Proximity Of Peabody Has Allowed Emphasis To DEBATING STAFF
Interior of Former Activities
Building to Be Converted
Into Studio
FOUR CANDIDATES
ELECTED TO CLUB
Ness, Harris Make Acting
Staff; Passagno, Green,
Appointed to Production Staff
On Sunday afternoon, at 4 P. M.,
the active members of the Barnstormers Club held a meeting at
Which plans were made for the remainder of the year, new members
Were elected and future policies of
the club were decided upon.
The club considered the improvements to the Barn first. Lester Haas,
the chairman of the committee in
charge of these improvements,
stated that action for rejuvenation
would be taken immediately by the
University authorities as soon as
the club reported what arrangements and color scheme they desired their studio to be furnished
in. The floors are to be scraped
and varnished and made available
for dancing, should the club -wish
to hold their functions there.
Expensee Prohibits Discussion

The expense to the University,
however, prohibited any further decisions to be made final. It is possible to repaint walls a different hue
or to scrape off the paint entirely
and leave only the bare bricks.
The club authorized the chairman
of the improvements committee to
get estimates on the two possibilities for improvements, namely:
Painting or scraping the walls.
Officies To Be Renovated

The offices of the Business Manager and Production Manager are to
be reconstructed and renovated.
There is to be a special room
devoted to the Club members,
rugs on the floor, ashtrays, and all
modern conveniences where the
elite may rest their weary bones between scenes of the play, during
practice seasons or between classes.
It will be a friendly place to convene where the club members may
express philosophical thoughts or
Propose ideals of the future Barnstormers.
Due to indecision on the Club's
Part, there will be a meeting held
cm Wednesday night after the chairman has conferred with the University authorities on the building.
The sole purpose of this meeting is
to discuss the studio possibilities
and other incidentals.

Be Placed On Books Peculiar To Research
When Daniel Coit Gilman,
founder and first president of the
Johns Hopkins University, first
gave serious thought to the proposed
university, he realized that many
books would be necessary to the success of the plan. He therefore
bought up many books concerning
other colleges, both here and abroad.
These books formed the beginning
of the Johns Hopkins library system, that now has accumulated over
4)0,000 bound volumes.
The collection of books in 1874,
when the University was in the embryonic stage. One of the first purchases was that of a one volume
edition of Webster's dictionary, and
onother one of the original volumes
was a Latin grammar, written by
Basil Gildersleeve, who later became
the first Professor of Greek in the
University.
Available Funds Limited

Due to the fact that the funds
available for the purpose of buying
books was very limited, the motivating spirits of the University in
its early days decided to get only
those books that were not available
at other libraries in the city. In
1876, the Peabody .Institute, situated within a few blocks of the lawn
that formed the Hopkins "campus"
had one of the best libraries suited
to scholarly research in this part of
the country, and it was felt to be a
great loss of time and money to try
to duplicate their collection.

As the situation stood at the time
when the Hopkins University moved
into the two converted houses that
were to be its home for some time,
books were bought mainly on request of the faculty and graduate
students. Under this plan, the library came to include volumes that
were especially valuable in research,
and was especially rich in bound
volumes of periodicals. These were
housed in Hopkins Hall in a room
that held two hundred people.
McCoy Gives $600,000

Many gifts increased the number
of volumes until in 1890, the library
outgrew its quarters. J. W. McCoy
bequeathed a fund of $600,000 to
the University which was available
for building purposes, and with this
money, McCoy Hall was built. It
was in the fourth floor of this building that the library found its new
home. Here the departmental library systemn was developed into its
present form. The main idea of this
plan was to put the books as near
to the department headquarters that
they concerned as was possible.
Chemical volumes were placed in
that laboratory, and books pertaining to other subjects were put at the
fingertips of the professors in question.
Further developments in the early
history of the lit4rary, notes as to
famous books and collections that
are now in it, and other items of interest will appear in further issues.

rushee, at the termination of the

S ITS title indicates, this
book is an attempt on the
part of Dr. Boas to show the
workings of the modern mind, to
contrast it with the Greek or classical mind, and to show in what these
differences consist.
In the author's preface, which in
a very brilliant manner, sums up the
entire scope of the essay, we find
the following paragraph:

A

In broadest terms, our modern
thought differs in three respects from
the thinking of the past. First—a
shift from final absolute • "truth" to
changing and growing "probability";
Second—the substitution of the notion
that change is growth for the notion
that it is mechanical impact; Third—
the substitution of what may be called
"will" for the "reason" as the source
of human acts.

The rest of the book consists of
an elaboration of the three fundamental differences in modern thinking,

City Welfare Board
Student Reception Hears Shaffer Finally Lands
New Men This Thursday
Asks Fraternity Aid Dr. Spencer on "Miracles', Job at Station W.C.B.M.
Last Sunday the 6th annual inwas
held under the auspices of the Epworth League of Mount Vernon
Place Church.
Two hundred foreign students,
both of the Johns Hopkins University, and the University of Maryland were the guests of the evening.
The social hour, beginning at 5
P. M., was followed by tea.

Prominent Engineer Will Deliver Ten Fraternities Agree to Care for
ternational student reception
Address at Assembly
Cases

Thursday's Assembly will be in
charge of Tau Beta Pi, honorary
Engineering fraternity and will be
used principally for the announcement and reception of newly-elected
members. An American engineer of
prominence will address the gathering.
A banquet will be given in honor
of the initiates on Friday evening,
at 7 o'clock, in the Southern Hotel.
The principal speaker will be R. C.
Disque, Dean of Drexel Institute,
who has been responsible for the
great forward strides which Drexel
has made in advancing from a secondary rating to the position of one
of the country's foremost engineering institutions.
It is expected that a large number of graduate members of Tau
Beta Pi will be present. Professor
Christy and Dean Whitehead will
speak, while H. Ridgely Warfield,
Hopkins graduate of 1927, will act
as toastmaster.

Fraternities at the University
were given a chance last Thursday
noon to make themselves felt in the
city in a practical way. Through the
efforts of a committee composed of
Lockard and Frey, a plan was outlined, at the Thursday Y. M. C. A.
luncheon, by which the fraternities
can work with the Family Welfare
Association in aiding needy families
in the City of Baltimore.
At the luncheon, Miss Anna D.
Ward, of the Welfare Association,
spoke, presenting the plan. The first
point to consider, she said, was that
destitute families nbt only require
aid at Christmas, but throughout the
year. The second was that the Association needed help during the
Christmas rush. Miss Ward presented a number of specific cases of
extremely needy families which the
fraternities can take into their

by Dr. John 0. Spencer, president
of the Morgan College, who spoke
on the topic, "Some Miracles of

FRIED'S

Mount, Linck to Attend
National Conference
National Student Y. M. C. A.'s
and Y. W. C. A.'s are holding a
National Student-Faculty Conference in Detroit, Mich., December
27 and 31. Mount, president of the
Hopkins Y. M. C. A., and Linck,
also a cabinet member, are the delegates from the local branch of the
(Cy:,

At the conference, being held under the auspices of the Student Associations, operating through Council of Christian Association, meetings discussing such problems as
social and religious life on the campus, educational systems and other
things of importance, will be held.
The first meeting will start at
2.30 on the 27th, at the Hotel Book
Cadillac, in Detroit, Mich., and will
continue until 5.30 on the 31st.

Professor M. P. Nilsson
Gives Illustrated Talk
In an illustrated lecture given yesterday in the Civil Engineering
Building, Prof. Martin Persson
Nilsson, Sather Lecturer at the
